item.title: By: Kevin Ball
item.dc:creator: Kevin Ball
item.description: Using jslint is a great suggestion. Â I recommend also integrating it with your IDE/text editor (for example in vim using jslint.vim), so you can see the suggestions and bug fixes inline as you're coding. Â Coding JS has gotten so much easier for me since I pulled this in.Â
item.content:encoded: Using jslint is a great suggestion. Â I recommend also integrating it with your IDE/text editor (for example in vim using jslint.vim), so you can see the suggestions and bug fixes inline as you’re coding. Â Coding JS has gotten so much easier for me since I pulled this in.Â

item.description: That does indeed help, many thanks! Â I've got a ton of follow-up questions, but I think I'll save you the headache and buy Javascript: The Good Parts for my Kindle!
item.content:encoded: That does indeed help, many thanks! Â I’ve got a ton of follow-up questions, but I think I’ll save you the headache and buy Javascript: The Good Parts for my Kindle!

item.title: By: Oliver Caldwell
item.dc:creator: Oliver Caldwell
item.description:
Â Interesting question. Basically without using prototype it will not work. When you create an instance of a class, x = new MyClass() for instance, the prototype of that function is copied into a new object, so the result of the "new" call is almost a copy of the prototype object.
If you do not use the prototype object then when you run x = new MyClass() x will not contain any of the functions. This is best explained in a fiddle though: http://jsfiddle.net/Wolfy87/SS3s6/
Hope this helps! :D
item.content:encoded:
Â Interesting question. Basically without using prototype it will not work. When you create an instance of a class, x = new MyClass() for instance, the prototype of that function is copied into a new object, so the result of the “new” call is almost a copy of the prototype object.

If you do not use the prototype object then when you run x = new MyClass() x will not contain any of the functions. This is best explained in a fiddle though: http://jsfiddle.net/Wolfy87/SS3s6/

Hope this helps! ðŸ˜€

item.title: By: AlexGemmell
item.dc:creator: AlexGemmell
item.content:encoded:
Quick question, why add your function via prototype rather than directly to the class?

Why:SomeClass.prototype.foo = function() { // code… };
Instead of:SomeClass.foo = function() { // code… };Forgive my basic understanding of prototype. Â I’m sure there’s a good reason!Or is this question out of the scope of this article? Â ðŸ™‚
